newsitem.title: USA: Concerns raised about crop insurance costs -- USDA.
newsitem.headline: Concerns raised about crop insurance costs -- USDA.

text.p: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and a Republican lawmaker are concerned about the costs of expansion of the crop revenue insurance coverage program, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said Friday.

"The (crop insurance) board met, and there are some concerns from OMB as to costs and Senator Lugar (R-Ind.) has indicated some concerns about costs," Glickman told reporters at an event to launch a rural development initiative.
"We're working on it with OMB. My personal hope is we can get it expanded," he said.

USDA is in the final weeks of negotiating with a private insurance company the terms of selling federally backed revenue insurance. A pilot program was run last year in Iowa and Nebraska. In December, USDA's crop insurance board okayed expanding coverage for certain spring crops but required some outstanding issues be ironed out.

OMB is concerned by the cost to the federal goverment if there are major losses in the next season, Catherine Woteki, acting USDA undersecretary for research and member of the crop insurance board told reporters.
Woteki also cited board concerns that the product is untried. "They only had one year of experience with this new instrument. We don't have complete data from the industry," she said.
Lugar wrote the secretary on Jan. 6 to express concern.
"The department is turning a limited pilot initiative into a national program without benefit of either clear congressional direction or sufficient actuarial experience," he wrote.
